summary:
Rare Comet G3 ATLAS Visible Tonight After 160,000 Years: Where And How To Watch

Date: January 13, 2025

Source: Astronomical News

Skywatchers around the world are in for an incredible spectacle tonight, as Comet G3 ATLAS (C/2024) reaches its peak brightness, a sight that won’t be seen again for 160,000 years.

  • The comet was discovered in April 2024 in Chile.
  • It will reach its closest approach to the Sun at a distance of 8.7 million miles.
  • The best viewing will be in the Southern Hemisphere just after sunset.
  • Observers may need binoculars for better visibility, especially in the Northern Hemisphere.
“Don’t miss this chance to be part of a moment that won’t return for millennia.”

This is a rare opportunity for astronomers and skywatchers to witness a comet that may not survive its journey near the Sun.

Balanced vegetarian diets for aspiring athletes: What you need to know - The Indian Express
summary:
Balanced Vegetarian Diets for Aspiring Athletes: What You Need to Know

Publication Date: January 13, 2024

Source: The Indian Express

This article discusses the essential nutrients that vegetarian athletes must focus on to optimize their performance, recovery, and overall health.

  • Vegetarian athletes may struggle to get adequate protein, iron, calcium, vitamin B12, and omega-3 fatty acids.
  • Plant proteins from whole grains, quinoa, lentils, and beans can meet protein needs effectively.
  • Combining vitamin C-rich foods with iron-rich foods can enhance iron absorption.
  • Vitamin B12 may need to be supplemented or acquired from fortified foods.
  • Calcium and omega-3 fatty acids can be found in tofu, almonds, flaxseeds, chia seeds, and walnuts.
  • A whole-food-based vegetarian diet should include seasonal fruits, vegetables, healthy fats, and electrolyte-rich drinks for athletes.
'A balanced, whole-food-based vegetarian diet is crucial for maximizing energy, recovery, and general well-being.'

In conclusion, aspiring athletes can thrive on a vegetarian diet by carefully planning their nutrition to meet their unique dietary requirements.
newTitle: Balanced Vegetarian Diets for Aspiring Athletes: Key Insights

title: Spacewalk Preps, Biology Research Wrap Up Week Aboard Station - Space Daily
summary:
Spacewalk Preps, Biology Research Wrap Up Week Aboard Station

Date: Jan 13, 2025 | Source: NASA Blogs

The Expedition 72 crew aboard the International Space Station has prepared for upcoming spacewalks while conducting vital biotechnology research aimed at enhancing health both on Earth and in space.

  • Two spacewalks are scheduled for Jan. 16 and Jan. 23 to service research equipment and search for microbes.
  • Astronauts Nick Hague and Suni Williams will lead the first spacewalk, addressing multiple maintenance tasks including a light leak on the NICER X-ray telescope.
  • Additional research includes processing micro-algae samples for potential food and oxygen production.
  • Cosmonauts are also studying balance and orientation in weightlessness.
“Hague began his day processing samples of micro-algae that may be able to produce food to sustain crews.”

This work underscores the significance of human research aboard the ISS for advancing both space exploration and terrestrial applications.
newTitle: Spacewalk Preparations and Biological Research Conclude Aboard ISS

NASA's LEXI Mission Will Explore Earth’s Magnetic Shield from the Moon - Gadgets 360
summary:
NASA's LEXI Mission Will Explore Earth’s Magnetic Shield from the Moon

Publication Date: January 15, 2025

Source: Live Science

NASA is preparing to deploy the Lunar Environment Heliospheric X-ray Imager (LEXI) to the moon, aiming to provide groundbreaking observations of Earth's magnetic field.

  • LEXI will capture images of the magnetosphere's movements in response to solar wind.
  • The mission seeks to enhance understanding of space weather and its impact on satellites and electronics.
  • LEXI will monitor Earth's magnetosphere for six days, using low-energy X-rays.
  • Findings may improve predictions of geomagnetic storms affecting technological systems.
“Stronger solar winds cause the magnetosphere to compress, while weaker winds allow it to expand.” - Hyunju Connor, NASA

Understanding the interactions of Earth's magnetosphere is crucial for protecting terrestrial and space-based assets.
newTitle: NASA's LEXI Mission Will Explore Earth’s Magnetic Shield from the Moon

Japan's Wooden Satellite LignoSat Launched: Everything You Need to Know - Gadgets 360
summary:
Japan's Wooden Satellite LignoSat Launched: Everything You Need to Know

Publication Date: October 2023 | Source: Gadgets 360

In a significant milestone for space exploration, the world's first wooden satellite, LignoSat, has been successfully launched into Earth's orbit by the Japanese Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA).

  • LignoSat aims to explore the feasibility of wood as a sustainable material in satellite construction.
  • The satellite was developed using honoki magnolia wood, known for its durability and resistance to environmental stresses.
  • LignoSat was launched aboard SpaceX-31's Dragon Cargo Vehicle from the International Space Station.
  • The satellite is equipped with sensors to monitor stress, temperature variations, and radiation exposure.
  • The initiative could lead to more eco-friendly solutions in satellite technology.
“If successful, this initiative could set a precedent for the adoption of sustainable practices in the global space industry.”

The development of sustainable materials for satellite construction is crucial as concerns over the environmental impact of space missions grow.
newTitle: Japan's Wooden Satellite LignoSat Launched: Everything You Need to Know

title: NASA warns: China’s Three Gorges Dam could slow Earth’s rotation by 0.06 seconds; here’s how - The Times of India
summary:
NASA warns: China’s Three Gorges Dam could slow Earth’s rotation by 0.06 seconds; here’s how

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Times of India

This article discusses NASA's findings about the Three Gorges Dam in China, noting that its construction and operation have led to a measurable change in the Earth's rotation, specifically a slowdown by 0.06 microseconds per day.

  • NASA's study indicates that the dam's large water reservoir redistributes Earth's mass, affecting rotational dynamics.
  • The Three Gorges Dam is the world's largest hydroelectric dam, significantly contributing to renewable energy production.
  • Human activities, such as constructing dams, have broader implications for Earth's physical properties and dynamism.
  • The article highlights the growing human capacity to influence the Earth's natural systems.
“The effect of the Three Gorges Dam on Earth's rotation is tantamount to the immense and often invisible power that human ingenuity has over planetary systems.”

The findings emphasize the interdependence of human engineering and the natural world, urging responsible environmental stewardship due to the long-term effects of such large projects.
newTitle: NASA warns: China’s Three Gorges Dam could slow Earth’s rotation by 0.06 seconds; here’s how

title: Starwatch: Mars at its brightest, closest to Earth and in conjunction with moon - The Guardian
summary:
Starwatch: Mars at its Brightest and Closest to Earth

Publication Date: January 12, 2023 Source: The Guardian

Currently, Mars is at its closest approach to Earth and is set to experience a spectacular conjunction with the moon. This astronomical event will provide an excellent opportunity for skywatchers.

  • Mars has recently reached its closest distance to Earth, separated by 59.7 million miles (96.1 million kilometers).
  • This proximity occurs every two years, similar to Earth lapping Mars.
  • The next significant event occurs on January 16, with Mars reaching “opposition,” making it appear at its brightest.
  • The moon will pass near Mars on January 14, providing an additional highlight for observers.
“Mars reflects the most light that it can, meaning the planet will be at its brightest.”

This celestial event underlines the dynamic relationship between Earth and Mars, providing a unique spectacle for astronomy enthusiasts.
newTitle: Starwatch: Mars at its Brightest and Closest to Earth

title: Once-in-a-lifetime comet visible tonight. It won't return for 1,60,000 years - India Today
summary:
Once-in-a-lifetime comet visible tonight. It won't return for 160,000 years

Published On: Jan 13, 2025
Published By: Sibu Kumar Tripathi

Tonight, skywatchers around the world can witness Comet G3 ATLAS (C/2024) at its peak brightness, an event that occurs once every 160,000 years.

  • The comet will come within 8.7 million miles of the Sun.
  • It is expected to shine at around -3.2 magnitude, visible to the naked eye under good conditions.
  • Best viewing opportunities are in the Southern Hemisphere shortly after sunset.
  • Astronaut Don Pettit captured images of the comet from the International Space Station.
  • Recent observations show a dramatic increase in brightness following a January 2, 2025 outburst.
Astronomers are closely monitoring G3 ATLAS as it approaches perihelion, raising questions about the comet's stability.

This once-in-a-lifetime event is generating excitement among stargazers and scientists alike as it makes its historic pass through our skies.
newTitle: Comet G3 ATLAS: A Rare Celestial Event Visible Tonight

title: Once-in-a-lifetime Comet G3 ATLAS (C/2024) visible tonight. It won't return for 1,60,000 years - India Today
summary:
Once-in-a-lifetime comet visible tonight. It won't return for 160,000 years

Published On: Jan 13, 2025 Published By: Sibu Kumar Tripathi

Skywatchers are in for a spectacular treat tonight as Comet G3 ATLAS (C/2024) reaches its peak brightness, an event expected only once every 160,000 years.

  • Discovered on April 5, 2024, by the ATLAS in Chile.
  • The comet is approaching its perihelion, coming within 8.7 million miles of the Sun.
  • Recent brightness increases predict it could outshine Venus and Jupiter, with a visibility magnitude of around -3.2.
  • The best viewing opportunities are in the Southern Hemisphere shortly after sunset.
  • Astronomers are monitoring for potential fragmentation as the comet approaches the Sun.
“It promises to leave an indelible mark on the astronomical calendar.”

It's a unique opportunity for observers, particularly those equipped with binoculars, to witness the brilliance of this historic comet.

title: Can astronauts have sex in space, how will a child born in space look like? - India.com
summary:
Can astronauts have sex in space, how will a child born in space look like?

Published Date: Not specified Source: India.com

Life Beyond Earth: Humans have always been curious about life beyond Earth, fueling explorations like sending rovers to Mars. This curiosity leads to questions about human reproduction and childbirth in space.

Pregnancy in Space

Female astronauts can potentially become pregnant in space, but factors such as zero gravity and radiation can adversely affect fetal development. NASA has no clear policy on intimate relationships in space.

Challenges of Childbirth

  • Zero gravity causes astronauts to lose up to 12% bone density in six months, complicating childbirth.
  • Radiation exposure can lead to genetic abnormalities in newborns.
  • A child born in space may have physical differences, such as larger skulls due to the absence of gravity.

Animal Reproduction in Space

Experiments have been conducted on animals, such as sending freeze-dried mouse sperm to space for six years, resulting in healthy offspring back on Earth. However, implications for human reproduction remain uncertain.

The journey to establishing human life in space continues with many challenges to overcome, especially concerning reproduction.
newTitle: Can Astronauts Have Sex in Space and Childbirth Implications?

Space Agriculture Market Expected to Grow at 18.20% CAGR, Reaching USD 12.7 Billion by 2030 - openPR
summary:
Space Agriculture Market Expected to Grow at 18.20% CAGR, Reaching USD 12.7 Billion by 2030

Publication Date: 2023

Source: openPR

The Space Agriculture Market is projected to grow at a robust CAGR of 18.20%, from USD 5.32 billion in 2023 to approximately USD 12.7 billion by 2030, driven by advancements in agricultural technology and increasing investments in space exploration.

  • The market growth is influenced by the need for self-sustaining life support systems in long-duration space missions.
  • Technologies like hydroponics, aeroponics, and AI-enabled automation are transforming agricultural practices in microgravity.
  • Countries such as Vietnam, Thailand, Japan, and South Korea are emerging as key players in the space agriculture sector.
  • The US remains a leader due to its significant investments and advancements, particularly through NASA and private companies.
“Space agriculture plays a critical role in providing food, oxygen, and psychological benefits for sustainable colonization on celestial bodies.”

This sector not only aims to enhance food production in space but also opens avenues for agricultural innovation on Earth, aligning with the growing consumer desire for sustainability.
newTitle: Space Agriculture Market Expected to Grow at 18.20% CAGR, Reaching USD 12.7 Billion by 2030

BepiColombo Just Completed its Sixth Flyby of Mercury. Here are the Best Images - Universe Today
summary:
BepiColombo Completes Sixth Flyby of Mercury with Stunning Images

Publication Date: N/A Source: ESA

BepiColombo has successfully completed its sixth flyby of Mercury, capturing remarkable images of the planet as it prepares for its final orbit, set for 2026. This mission, a collaboration between ESA and JAXA, is crucial for understanding the characteristics of Mercury.

  • BepiColombo is maneuvering closer to Mercury with each flyby.
  • The spacecraft captured stunning images from just a few hundred kilometers above Mercury's surface.
  • Mercury is the smallest and closest planet to the Sun, with extreme temperature variations.
  • Two orbiters, the ESA’s Mercury Planetary Orbiter and JAXA’s Mercury Magnetospheric Orbiter, are involved in this mission.
  • First images from the flyby revealed craters, volcanic plains, and evidence of frozen water.
The craters Prokofiev, Kandinsky, Tolkien, and Gordimer can be seen with their permanently dark floors.

The successful sixth flyby marks a significant step in BepiColombo's mission, bringing us closer to understanding Mercury's geology and history as it edges towards its final orbit.
newTitle: BepiColombo Completes Sixth Flyby of Mercury with Stunning Images

title: A rare look at NASA’s next sharp-eyed space telescope - The Washington Post
summary:
A rare look at NASA’s next sharp-eyed space telescope

Publication Date: Unknown Source: Unknown

The next great space telescope will study distant galaxies and faraway planets from an orbital outpost about a million miles from Earth, currently being assembled in a large chamber at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center.

  • The telescope will observe the universe from an orbital position approximately one million miles from Earth.
  • Assembly of the telescope occurs in the Clean Room at the NASA Goddard Space Flight Center in Maryland.
  • The Clean Room is a large space, measuring 125 feet long, 100 feet wide, and 90 feet high.
  • This facility can accommodate nearly 30 stacked tractor-trailers side by side.
No notable quotes or statistics provided in the article.

This assembly process is pivotal for enabling the telescope to achieve its mission of exploring distant galaxies and planets.
newTitle: A rare look at NASA’s next sharp-eyed space telescope

title: NASA Says Spacecraft Made Closest-Ever Pass to Sun - VOA Learning English
summary:
NASA Says Spacecraft Made Closest-Ever Pass to Sun

Publication Date: December 24, 2023 | Source: VOA Learning English

The Parker Solar Probe has made history by passing within 6.1 million kilometers of the Sun, the closest any spacecraft has ever approached.

  • The probe, launched in August 2018, studies the Sun's corona and solar wind.
  • NASA confirmed the spacecraft is safe and successfully communicated after the pass.
  • Speed records were set, with the probe traveling at up to 692,000 kilometers per hour.
  • This mission aids in understanding solar impacts on technology and search for habitable worlds.
  • Data from the Parker Solar Probe has provided insights on solar wind speeds, reaching up to 1.6 million kilometers per hour.
“Flying this close to the sun is a historic moment in humanity’s first mission to a star.” - Nicky Fox, NASA’s Associate Administrator

This achievement marks a significant advancement in solar exploration, enhancing our understanding of solar phenomena and their effects on our solar system.
newTitle: NASA's Parker Solar Probe Sets Record for Closest Approach to the Sun
